eu.zidek.augustin.minuscule

Interface MGeometricObjectPainter

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    MLabelPainter, MLinePainter, MPointPainter, MPolygonPainter, MRectanglePainter, MShapePainter

    public interface MGeometricObjectPainter
    An interface for strategy that draws a given object. Each canvas object that implements MObject has to have a strategy implementing this interface that is able to draw this object. There are two advantages in holding this in a separate class (not as a method of each MObject implementation):
    1) The MObject implementations are lighter, as they all share this code and hence only one strategy class can be reused for multiple OBject implementations of the same type.
    2) Code clarity and using the principle "Single class, single responsibility". Naming convention: For an M[object name] use M[object name]Painter
    Author:
    Augustin Zidek

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void paint(MGeometricObject object, java.awt.Graphics2D g2d)
      Method called by the Canvas when painting the object.

    • Method Detail

      • paint

        void paint(MGeometricObject object,
           java.awt.Graphics2D g2d)
        Method called by the Canvas when painting the object. This method receives the Graphics2D held internally by the Canvas and paints the object on it. E.g. if there was an object House and corresponding HousePainter<House>, this method would draw the bottom yellow square, two blue squares for windows, a red triangle as a roof. If you want to have direct (low-level) access to the graphics, define this method when adding own custom complex shapes and draw directly to the given Graphics2D object using appropriate methods from the Java libraries. If you want to define your own shape using Minuscule objects only, use preferably the draw method in the object itself.
        Parameters:
        object - The object to be drawn
        g2d - The Graphics2D on which the object should paint itself
